Norm of Random Variables

Posted on 2021-03-27 Edited on 2024-03-11

Fix probability space (Ω,F,Pr⁡)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \Pr)(Ω,F,Pr), for real number p>0p > 0p>0, let LpL_pLp​ denote the vector space of real value random variable for which E∣X∣p<∞\mathbb{E} |X|^p < \inftyE∣X∣p<∞.

For p≥1p \ge 1p≥1, the ppp norm ∥X∥p\Vert X \Vert_p∥X∥p​ of a random variable X∈LpX \in L_pX∈Lp​ is defined as

∥X∥p=(E[∣X∣p])1/p. \Vert X \Vert_p = \left( \mathbb{E} \big[ |X|^p \big] \right)^{1 / p}. ∥X∥p​=(E[∣X∣p])1/p.

Norm

∥X∥p\Vert X \Vert_p∥X∥p​ is a norm.

Proof. This can be proven directly by Minkowski’s inequality. For completeness, we give the details here. Let X,Y∈LpX, Y \in L_pX,Y∈Lp​, and let a=∥X∥pa = \Vert X \Vert_pa=∥X∥p​ and b=∥Y∥pb = \Vert Y \Vert_pb=∥Y∥p​. We want to prove that

∥X+Y∥p≤a+b⟺∥aa+b⋅Xa+aa+b⋅Ya∥p≤1. \Vert X + Y \Vert_p \le a + b \Longleftrightarrow \left\Vert \frac{a}{ a + b} \cdot \frac{X}{a} + \frac{a}{ a + b} \cdot \frac{Y}{a} \right\Vert_p \le 1. ∥X+Y∥p​≤a+b⟺∥∥∥∥∥​a+ba​⋅aX​+a+ba​⋅aY​∥∥∥∥∥​p​≤1.

It suffices to assume that ∥X∥p=∥Y∥p=1\Vert X \Vert_p = \Vert Y \Vert_p = 1∥X∥p​=∥Y∥p​=1 and prove that

For t∈[0,1]t \in [0, 1]t∈[0,1], ∥tX+(1−t)Y∥p≤1\Vert t X + (1 - t) Y \Vert_p \le 1∥tX+(1−t)Y∥p​≤1.

This is much easier to prove as we can take the power of ppp of both side and show that:

∥tX+(1−t)Y∥pp=E[∣tX+(1−t)Y∣p]≤E[∣tX∣p+∣(1−t)Y∣p]=E[∣tX∣p]+E[∣(1−t)Y∣p]=tp∥X∥pp+(1−t)p∥Y∥pp≤t+(1−t)=1. \begin{aligned} \Vert t X + (1 - t) Y \Vert_p^p &= \mathbb{E}[ |t X + (1 - t) Y |^p ] \\ &\le \mathbb{E}[ | tX |^p + | (1 - t) Y|^p ] \\ &= \mathbb{E}[ | tX |^p ] + \mathbb{E} [ | ( 1 - t) Y|^p ] \\ &= t^p \Vert X \Vert_p^p + ( 1 - t)^p \Vert Y \Vert_p^p \\ &\le t + (1 - t) \\ &= 1. \end{aligned} ∥tX+(1−t)Y∥pp​​=E[∣tX+(1−t)Y∣p]≤E[∣tX∣p+∣(1−t)Y∣p]=E[∣tX∣p]+E[∣(1−t)Y∣p]=tp∥X∥pp​+(1−t)p∥Y∥pp​≤t+(1−t)=1.​

□\square□

Properties

Theorem. For 0≤p≤q0 \le p \le q0≤p≤q, (E[∣X∣p])1/p≤(E[∣X∣q])1/q\big( \mathbb{E} [ |X|^p ] \big)^{1 / p} \le \big( \mathbb{E} [ |X|^q ] \big)^{1 / q}(E[∣X∣p])1/p≤(E[∣X∣q])1/q.

Corollary For 1≤p≤q1 \le p \le q1≤p≤q, ∥X∥p≤∥X∥q\Vert X \Vert_p \le \Vert X \Vert_q∥X∥p​≤∥X∥q​.

Proof. By convexity of the function y=∣x∣q/py = |x|^{q / p}y=∣x∣q/p, we have

∣E[∣X∣p]∣q/p≤E[∣∣X∣p∣q/p]=E[∣X∣q] \begin{aligned} \Big| \mathbb{E} \big[ |X|^p \big] \Big|^{q / p} \le \mathbb{E} \left[ \Big| |X|^p \Big|^{q / p} \right] = \mathbb{E} \left[ |X|^q \right] \end{aligned} ∣∣∣∣​E[∣X∣p]∣∣∣∣​q/p≤E[∣∣∣∣​∣X∣p∣∣∣∣​q/p]=E[∣X∣q]​

Raising both hand sides to the power of 1/q1 / q1/q finish the proof.

□\square□

Let X1,...,Xn∈LpX_1, ..., X_n \in L_pX1​,...,Xn​∈Lp​ be independent random variables and let r1,...,rnr_1, ... ,r_nr1​,...,rn​ be independent Rademacher random variables. Then

∥∑i∈[n]Xi−E[∑i∈[n]Xi]∥p≤2⋅∥∑i∈[n]riXi∥p \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i - \mathbb{E} \left[ \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i \right] \right\Vert_p \le 2 \cdot \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } r_i X_i \right\Vert_p ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−E⎣⎢⎡​i∈[n]∑​Xi​⎦⎥⎤​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​≤2⋅∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​ri​Xi​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​

Proof. For i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], let YiY_iYi​ be independent copy of XiX_iXi​. Then

∥∑i∈[n]Xi−E[∑i∈[n]Xi]∥p=∥∑i∈[n]Xi−EY[∑i∈[n]Yi]∥p=(EX[∣∑i∈[n]Xi−EY[∑i∈[n]Yi]∣p])1/p≤(EXEY[∣∑i∈[n]Xi−∑i∈[n]Yi∣p])1/p(Jensen)=∥∑i∈[n](Xi−Yi)∥p \begin{aligned} \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i - \mathbb{E} \left[ \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i \right] \right\Vert_p &= \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i - \mathbb{E}_Y \left[ \sum_{i \in [n] } Y_i \right] \right\Vert_p \\ &= \left( \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i - \mathbb{E}_Y \left[ \sum_{i \in [n] } Y_i \right] \right|^p \right] \right)^{1 / p} \\ &\le \left( \mathbb{E}_X \mathbb{E}_Y \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i - \sum_{i \in [n] } Y_i \right|^p \right] \right)^{1 / p} &( \text{Jensen}) \\ &= \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } (X_i - Y_i) \right\Vert_p \end{aligned} ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−E⎣⎢⎡​i∈[n]∑​Xi​⎦⎥⎤​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​​=∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−EY​⎣⎢⎡​i∈[n]∑​Yi​⎦⎥⎤​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​=⎝⎛​EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−EY​⎣⎢⎡​i∈[n]∑​Yi​⎦⎥⎤​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎞​1/p≤⎝⎛​EX​EY​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−i∈[n]∑​Yi​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎞​1/p=∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​(Xi​−Yi​)∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​​(Jensen)​

Let Z=(Z1,...,Zn)Z = (Z_1, ..., Z_n)Z=(Z1​,...,Zn​) be a sequence of independent random variables, such that either Zi=Xi−YiZ_i = X_i - Y_iZi​=Xi​−Yi​ or Zi=Yi−XiZ_i = Y_i - X_iZi​=Yi​−Xi​. Let Γ={Z}\Gamma = \{ Z \}Γ={Z} be the set of 2n2^n2n such sequences. As Xi−YiX_i - Y_iXi​−Yi​ and Yi−XiY_i - X_iYi​−Xi​ have the same distributions, we have for Z∈ΓZ \in \GammaZ∈Γ,

EZ[∣∑i∈[n]Zi∣p]=EX,Y[∣∑i∈[n]Xi−Yi∣p]. \mathbb{E}_Z \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n] } Z_i \right|^p \right] = \mathbb{E}_{X, Y} \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n]} X_i - Y_i \right|^p \right]. EZ​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Zi​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​=EX,Y​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−Yi​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​.

Therefore,

1∣Γ∣∑Z∈ΓEZ[∣∑i∈[n]Zi∣p]=EX,Y[∣∑i∈[n]Xi−Yi∣p]. \frac{1}{ |\Gamma| } \sum_{ Z \in \Gamma } \mathbb{E}_Z \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n] } Z_i \right|^p \right] = \mathbb{E}_{X, Y} \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n]} X_i - Y_i \right|^p \right]. ∣Γ∣1​Z∈Γ∑​EZ​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Zi​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​=EX,Y​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−Yi​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​.

If R=(r1,...,rn)R = (r_1, ..., r_n)R=(r1​,...,rn​) are Rademacher random variables, then (r1(X1−Y1),...,rn(Xn−Yn)(r_1 (X_1 - Y_1), ..., r_n(X_n - Y_n)(r1​(X1​−Y1​),...,rn​(Xn​−Yn​) gives a uniformly sequence in Γ\GammaΓ. It holds that

EREX,Y[∣∑i∈[n]ri(Xi−Yi)∣p]=1∣Γ∣∑Z∈ΓEZ[∣∑i∈[n]Zi∣p]=EX,Y[∣∑i∈[n]Xi−Yi∣p]. \mathbb{E}_R \mathbb{E}_{X, Y} \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n]} r_i (X_i - Y_i) \right|^p \right] = \frac{1}{ |\Gamma| } \sum_{ Z \in \Gamma } \mathbb{E}_Z \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n] } Z_i \right|^p \right] = \mathbb{E}_{X, Y} \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n]} X_i - Y_i \right|^p \right]. ER​EX,Y​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​ri​(Xi​−Yi​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​=∣Γ∣1​Z∈Γ∑​EZ​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Zi​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​=EX,Y​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−Yi​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​.

Hence,

∥∑i∈[n]Xi−E[∑i∈[n]Xi]∥p≤∥∑i∈[n](Xi−Yi)∥p=∥∑i∈[n]ri(Xi−Yi)∥p≤2∥∑i∈[n]riXi∥p \begin{aligned} \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i - \mathbb{E} \left[ \sum_{i \in [n] } X_i \right] \right\Vert_p &\le \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } (X_i - Y_i) \right\Vert_p \\ &= \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } r_i(X_i - Y_i) \right\Vert_p \\ &\le 2 \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } r_i X_i \right\Vert_p \end{aligned} ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​Xi​−E⎣⎢⎡​i∈[n]∑​Xi​⎦⎥⎤​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​​≤∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​(Xi​−Yi​)∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​=∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​ri​(Xi​−Yi​)∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​≤2∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​ri​Xi​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​​

□\square□

Remark: We can simply the argument as follows. For a fixed sequence (r1,...,rn)∈{−1,1}n(r_1,..., r_n) \in \{-1, 1 \}^n(r1​,...,rn​)∈{−1,1}n, the sequence (r1(X1−Y1),...,rn(Xn−Yn))(r_1(X_1 - Y_1), ..., r_n(X_n - Y_n) )(r1​(X1​−Y1​),...,rn​(Xn​−Yn​)) has the same distribution as (X1−Yn,...,Xn−Yn)(X_1 - Y_n, ..., X_n - Y_n)(X1​−Yn​,...,Xn​−Yn​). Averaging over all such possible sequences gives that

∥∑i∈[n](Xi−Yi)∥p=∥∑i∈[n]ri(Xi−Yi)∥p. \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } (X_i - Y_i) \right\Vert_p = \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n] } r_i(X_i - Y_i) \right\Vert_p. ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​(Xi​−Yi​)∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​=∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​ri​(Xi​−Yi​)∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​.

Let X1,...,XnX_1, ..., X_nX1​,...,Xn​ be independent and mean zero random variables and let Y1,...,YnY_1, ..., Y_nY1​,...,Yn​ be independent copies of them. Then for any (ai,j)(a_{i, j} )(ai,j​) and for p≥1p \ge 1p≥1, it holds that

∥∑i≠jai,jXiXj∥p≤4∥∑i≠jai,jXiYj∥p \begin{aligned} \left\Vert \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j \right\Vert_p \le 4\left\Vert \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i Y_j \right\Vert_p \end{aligned} ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​≤4∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Yj​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​​

Proof. Let B1,...,BnB_1, ..., B_nB1​,...,Bn​ be independent Bernoulli random variables each of expectation 1/21 / 21/2. Then

∥∑i≠jai,jXiXj∥p=(EX[∣∑i≠jai,jXiXj∣p])1/p=(EX[∣4EB[∑i≠jai,jXiXjBi(1−Bj)]∣p])1/p≤(EX[EB[4∣∑i≠jai,jXiXjBi(1−Bj)∣p]])1/p(Jensen)=4(EXEB[∣∑i≠jai,jXiXjBi(1−Bj)∣p])1/p=4(EBEX[∣∑i≠jai,jXiXjBi(1−Bj)∣p])1/p \begin{aligned} \left\Vert \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j \right\Vert_p &= \left( \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j \right|^p \right]\right)^{1 / p} \\ &= \left( \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| 4 \mathbb{E}_B \left[ \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j B_i (1 - B_j) \right] \right|^p \right]\right)^{1 / p} \\ &\le \left( \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \mathbb{E}_B \left[ 4 \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j B_i (1 - B_j) \right|^p \right] \right]\right)^{1 / p} & (\text{Jensen} ) \\ &= 4 \left( \mathbb{E}_X \mathbb{E}_B \left[ \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j B_i (1 - B_j) \right|^p \right]\right)^{1 / p} \\ &= 4 \left( \mathbb{E}_B \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j B_i (1 - B_j) \right|^p \right]\right)^{1 / p} \end{aligned} ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​​=⎝⎛​EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎞​1/p=⎝⎛​EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​4EB​⎣⎢⎡​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​Bi​(1−Bj​)⎦⎥⎤​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎞​1/p≤⎝⎛​EX​⎣⎢⎡​EB​⎣⎢⎡​4∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​Bi​(1−Bj​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎞​1/p=4⎝⎛​EX​EB​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​Bi​(1−Bj​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎞​1/p=4⎝⎛​EB​EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​Bi​(1−Bj​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎞​1/p​(Jensen)​

Question to ponder: Under what condition can we exchange the order of expectation (integration)?

But

EBEX[∣∑i≠jai,jXiXjBi(1−Bj)∣p]≤max⁡BEX[∣∑i≠jai,jXiXjBi(1−Bj)∣p]. \mathbb{E}_B \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j B_i (1 - B_j) \right|^p \right] \le \max_B \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j B_i (1 - B_j) \right|^p \right]. EB​EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​Bi​(1−Bj​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​≤Bmax​EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​Bi​(1−Bj​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​.

Let

B∗=(b1∗,...,bn∗)=arg⁡max⁡BEX[∣∑i≠jai,jXiXjBi(1−Bj)∣p] B^* = (b^*_1, ..., b^*_n) = \arg \max_{B} \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j B_i (1 - B_j) \right|^p \right] B∗=(b1∗​,...,bn∗​)=argBmax​EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​Bi​(1−Bj​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​

Define S≐{i:bi∗=1}S \doteq \{ i : b^*_i = 1 \}S≐{i:bi∗​=1}. Then

EX[∣∑i≠jai,jXiXjbi∗(1−bj∗)∣p]=EX[∣∑i∈S,j∉Sai,jXiXj∣p]=EX,Y[∣∑i∈S,j∉Sai,jXiYj∣p]\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \neq j} a_{i,j} X_i X_j b^*_i (1 - b^*_j) \right|^p \right] &= \mathbb{E}_X \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in S, j \notin S } a_{i,j} X_i X_j \right|^p \right] \\ &= \mathbb{E}_{X, Y} \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in S, j \notin S } a_{i,j} X_i Y_j \right|^p \right] \end{aligned} EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=j∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​bi∗​(1−bj∗​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​​=EX​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈S,j∈/S∑​ai,j​Xi​Xj​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​=EX,Y​⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈S,j∈/S∑​ai,j​Xi​Yj​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​p⎦⎥⎤​​

Let Z1,...,ZnZ_1, ..., Z_nZ1​,...,Zn​ and Z1′,...,Zn′Z_1', ..., Z_n'Z1′​,...,Zn′​ both be independent copies of X1,...,XnX_1, ..., X_nX1​,...,Xn​. Then

□\square□

The Poisson Approximation

Posted on 2021-03-22 Edited on 2022-02-10

Poisson Distribution

A discrete random variable XXX follows Poisson (ˈˈˈpwɑːsɒn) distribution, with a parameter λ\lambdaλ, if its probability mass function is given by

Pr⁡[X=k]=e−λλkk!,∀k∈N. \Pr[ X = k ] = e^{ - \lambda } \frac{ \lambda^k }{ k! }, \qquad \forall k \in \mathbb{N}. Pr[X=k]=e−λk!λk​,∀k∈N.

We can verify that the definition is valid:

∑k∈NPr⁡[X=k]=e−λ∑k∈Nλkk!=e−λeλ=1. \sum_{ k \in \mathbb{N} } \Pr[ X = k ] = e^{ - \lambda } \sum_{ k \in \mathbb{N} } \frac{ \lambda^k }{ k! } = e^{ - \lambda } e^{ \lambda } = 1. k∈N∑​Pr[X=k]=e−λk∈N∑​k!λk​=e−λeλ=1.

We use Pois(λ)\text{Pois}(\lambda)Pois(λ) to denote a Poisson distribution with parameter λ\lambdaλ.

Mean

Property. E[X]=λ\mathbb{E}[X] = \lambdaE[X]=λ.

Proof.

∑k∈NkPr⁡[X=k]=e−λλ∑1≤k∈Nλk−1(k−1)!=e−λλ∑k∈Nλkk!=λ. \sum_{ k \in \mathbb{N} } k\Pr[ X = k ] = e^{ - \lambda } \lambda \sum_{ 1 \le k \in \mathbb{N} } \frac{ \lambda^{k - 1} }{ (k - 1)! } = e^{ - \lambda } \lambda \sum_{ k \in \mathbb{N} } \frac{ \lambda^k }{ k! } = \lambda. k∈N∑​kPr[X=k]=e−λλ1≤k∈N∑​(k−1)!λk−1​=e−λλk∈N∑​k!λk​=λ.

□\square□

Variance

Property. Var[X]=λ\mathbb{Var}[X] = \lambdaVar[X]=λ.

Proof.

∑k∈Nk(k−1)Pr⁡[X=k]=e−λλ2∑2≤k∈Nλk−2(k−2)!=e−λλ2∑k∈Nλkk!=λ2. \sum_{ k \in \mathbb{N} } k(k - 1)\Pr[ X = k ] = e^{ - \lambda } \lambda^2 \sum_{ 2 \le k \in \mathbb{N} } \frac{ \lambda^{k - 2} }{ (k - 2)! } = e^{ - \lambda } \lambda^2 \sum_{ k \in \mathbb{N} } \frac{ \lambda^k }{ k! } = \lambda^2. k∈N∑​k(k−1)Pr[X=k]=e−λλ22≤k∈N∑​(k−2)!λk−2​=e−λλ2k∈N∑​k!λk​=λ2.

Hence,

Var[X]=∑k∈Nk2Pr⁡[X=k]−(E[X])2=∑k∈N(k(k−1)+k)Pr⁡[X=k]−(E[X])2=λ2+λ−λ2=λ. \begin{aligned} \mathbb{Var}[X] &= \sum_{ k \in \mathbb{N} } k^2 \Pr[ X = k ] - (\mathbb{E}[X] )^2 \\ &= \sum_{ k \in \mathbb{N} } ( k (k - 1) + k ) \Pr[ X = k ] - (\mathbb{E}[X] )^2 \\ &= \lambda^2 + \lambda - \lambda^2 \\ &= \lambda. \end{aligned} Var[X]​=k∈N∑​k2Pr[X=k]−(E[X])2=k∈N∑​(k(k−1)+k)Pr[X=k]−(E[X])2=λ2+λ−λ2=λ.​

□\square□

Sum of Two Independent Poisson Variable

Property. If X1∼Pois(λ1)X_1 \sim \text{Pois}(\lambda_1)X1​∼Pois(λ1​) and X2∼Pois(λ2)X_2 \sim \text{Pois}(\lambda_2)X2​∼Pois(λ2​), then X1+X2∼Pois(λ1+λ2)X_1 + X_2 \sim \text{Pois} (\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)X1​+X2​∼Pois(λ1​+λ2​).

Proof. For every k∈Nk \in \mathbb{N}k∈N,

Pr⁡[X1+X2=k]=∑a,b∈N,a+b=k(e−λ1λ1aa!)(e−λ2λ2bb!)=e−(λ1+λ2)1k!∑a,b∈N,a+b=kk!a!b!λ1aλ2b=e−(λ1+λ2)(λ1+λ2)kk!. \begin{aligned} \Pr[X_1 + X_2 = k] &= \sum_{a, b \in \mathbb{N}, a + b = k} \left( e^{- \lambda_1 } \frac{ \lambda_1^{a} }{ a! } \right) \left( e^{-\lambda_2 } \frac{ \lambda_2^b }{ b! } \right) \\ &= e^{- (\lambda_1 + \lambda_2) } \frac{1}{k!} \sum_{a, b \in \mathbb{N}, a + b = k} \frac{ k! }{ a! b! } \lambda_1^{a} \lambda_2^b \\ &= e^{- (\lambda_1 + \lambda_2) } \frac{ (\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)^k }{k!}. \end{aligned} Pr[X1​+X2​=k]​=a,b∈N,a+b=k∑​(e−λ1​a!λ1a​​)(e−λ2​b!λ2b​​)=e−(λ1​+λ2​)k!1​a,b∈N,a+b=k∑​a!b!k!​λ1a​λ2b​=e−(λ1​+λ2​)k!(λ1​+λ2​)k​.​

□\square□

Corollary. If Xi∼Pois(λi)X_i \sim \text{Pois}(\lambda_i)Xi​∼Pois(λi​) for every i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], then ∑i∈[n]Xi∼Pois(∑i∈[n]λi)\sum_{i \in [n] } X_i \sim \text{Pois} \left( \sum_{i \in [n] } \lambda_i \right)∑i∈[n]​Xi​∼Pois(∑i∈[n]​λi​).

Poisson Approximation

Binomial Distribution

The Poisson distribution can be used to approximate the limit of the binomial distribution, under some condition.

Poisson Limit Theorem. Suppose that ∀n∈N+\forall n \in \mathbb{N}^+∀n∈N+, the random variable YnY_nYn​ follows binomial distribution B(n,pn)\text{B}(n, p_n)B(n,pn​) and that npn=λn p_n = \lambdanpn​=λ. Let X∼Pois(λ)X \sim \text{Pois}(\lambda)X∼Pois(λ), then

lim⁡nPr⁡[Yn=k]=Pr⁡[X=k]. \lim_n \Pr[ Y_n = k ] = \Pr[ X = k ]. nlim​Pr[Yn​=k]=Pr[X=k].

Proof.

Pr⁡[Yn=k]=(nk)pnk(1−pn)n−k=n(n−1)...(n−k+1)k!pnk(1−pn)n−k=nk+O(nk−1)k!λknk(1−λn)n−k=λk(1+O(n−1))k!(1−λn)n−k \begin{aligned} \Pr[ Y_n = k ] &= \binom{n}{k } p_n^k (1 - p_n)^{n - k} \\ &= \frac{ n (n - 1) ... (n - k + 1) }{ k !} p_n^k ( 1 - p_n )^{n - k} \\ &= \frac{ n^k + O(n^{k - 1} ) }{ k !} \frac{ \lambda^k }{ n^k } \left( 1 - \frac{ \lambda }{ n } \right)^{n - k} \\ &= \frac{ \lambda^k \left( 1 + O( n^{-1} ) \right) }{ k !} \left( 1 - \frac{ \lambda }{ n } \right)^{n - k} \end{aligned} Pr[Yn​=k]​=(kn​)pnk​(1−pn​)n−k=k!n(n−1)...(n−k+1)​pnk​(1−pn​)n−k=k!nk+O(nk−1)​nkλk​(1−nλ​)n−k=k!λk(1+O(n−1))​(1−nλ​)n−k​

For fixed kkk, taking n→∞n \rightarrow \inftyn→∞, we have

λk(1+O(n−1))k!(1−λn)n−k→λkk!e−λ. \frac{ \lambda^k \left( 1 + O( n^{-1} ) \right) }{ k !} \left( 1 - \frac{ \lambda }{ n } \right)^{n - k} \rightarrow \frac{\lambda^k}{ k !} e^{-\lambda }. k!λk(1+O(n−1))​(1−nλ​)n−k→k!λk​e−λ.

Balls and Bins

We study the problem of throwing mmm balls into nnn bins randomly. For every i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], let YiY_iYi​ denote the number of balls in the iiith bin, which follows binomial distribution B(m,1/m)\text{B}(m, 1 / m)B(m,1/m). We have shown that YiY_iYi​ can be approximated by Xi∼Pois(m/n)X_i \sim \text{Pois}(m / n)Xi​∼Pois(m/n). In this section, we show a stronger result that the joint distribution of (Y1,...,Yn)(Y_1, ..., Y_n)(Y1​,...,Yn​) can be approximated by the joint distribution of Poisson random variables.

Theorem. ∀λ>0\forall \lambda > 0∀λ>0, let Xi∼Pois(λ)X_i \sim \text{Pois}(\lambda)Xi​∼Pois(λ) be independent random variables. Then the joint distribution of (X1,...,Xn)(X_1, ..., X_n)(X1​,...,Xn​) conditioned on ∑i∈[n]Xi=m\sum_{i \in [n]} X_i = m∑i∈[n]​Xi​=m is the same as (Y1,...,Yn)(Y_1, ..., Y_n)(Y1​,...,Yn​).

Remark: the theorem holds for ∀λ>0\forall \lambda > 0∀λ>0 and does not require that λ=m/n\lambda = m / nλ=m/n.

Proof. Let X=∑i∈[n]XiX = \sum_{i \in [n] } X_iX=∑i∈[n]​Xi​. We have proven that X∼Pois(nλ)X \sim \text{Pois}( n \lambda)X∼Pois(nλ). Hence, ∀k1,...,kn≥0\forall k_1, ..., k_n \ge 0∀k1​,...,kn​≥0, s.t. ∑i∈[n]ki=m\sum_{i \in [n] } k_i = m∑i∈[n]​ki​=m, we have

Pr⁡[X1=k1,X2=k2,...,Xn=kn∣X=m]=(∏i∈[n]e−λλkiki!)/(e−nλ(nλ)mm!)=e−nλλ∑i∈[n]kie−nλ(nλ)mm!∏i∈[n]ki!=(m!k1;k2;...;kn)1nm. \begin{aligned} \Pr[ X_1 = k_1, X_2 = k_2, ..., X_n = k_n \mid X = m ] &= \left( \prod_{i \in [n] } e^{-\lambda} \frac{ \lambda^{k_i} }{ k_i! } \right) / \left( e^{ - n\lambda} \frac{ (n\lambda)^m }{ m! } \right) \\ &= \frac{ e^{ - n \lambda} \lambda^{ \sum_{i \in [n] } k_i} }{ e^{ - n\lambda} (n\lambda)^m } \frac{ m! }{ \prod_{i \in [n] } k_i ! } \\ &= \binom{ m! }{ k_1; k_2; ...; k_n } \frac{1}{ n^m }. \end{aligned} Pr[X1​=k1​,X2​=k2​,...,Xn​=kn​∣X=m]​=⎝⎛​i∈[n]∏​e−λki​!λki​​⎠⎞​/(e−nλm!(nλ)m​)=e−nλ(nλ)me−nλλ∑i∈[n]​ki​​∏i∈[n]​ki​!m!​=(k1​;k2​;...;kn​m!​)nm1​.​

□\square□

Theorem [1]. ∀i∈[n]\forall i \in [n]∀i∈[n], Xi∼Pois(m/n)X_i \sim \text{Pois}(m / n)Xi​∼Pois(m/n). Let f(y1,...,yn)f(y_1, ..., y_n)f(y1​,...,yn​) be a nonnegative function. Then

E[f(Y1,...,Yn)]≤emE[f(X1,...,Xn)]. \mathbb{E}[ f(Y_1, ..., Y_n) ] \le e \sqrt{m} \mathbb{E}[ f(X_1, ..., X_n) ]. E[f(Y1​,...,Yn​)]≤em​E[f(X1​,...,Xn​)].

Proof. Let X=∑i∈[n]XiX = \sum_{i \in [n] } X_iX=∑i∈[n]​Xi​. Then X∼Pois(m)X \sim \text{Pois}(m)X∼Pois(m). As fff is nonnegative, it holds that

E[f(X1,...,Xn)]=∑k∈NE[f(X1,...,Xn)∣X=k]⋅Pr⁡[X=k]≥E[f(X1,...,Xn)∣X=m]⋅Pr⁡[X=m]=E[f(Y1,...,Yn)]⋅e−mmmm!≥E[f(Y1,...,Yn)]⋅e−m(m)m(em)m1em=E[f(Y1,...,Yn)]⋅1em, \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[ f(X_1, ..., X_n) ] &= \sum_{ k \in \mathbb{N} } \mathbb{E}[ f(X_1, ..., X_n) \mid X = k] \cdot \Pr[ X = k ] \\ &\ge \mathbb{E}[ f(X_1, ..., X_n) \mid X = m] \cdot \Pr[ X = m ] \\ &= \mathbb{E}[ f(Y_1, ..., Y_n) ] \cdot e^{ - m } \frac{ m^m }{ m! } \\ &\ge \mathbb{E}[ f(Y_1, ..., Y_n) ] \cdot e^{ - m } (m)^m \left( \frac{e}{m} \right)^m \frac{1}{ e \sqrt{m} } \\ &= \mathbb{E}[ f(Y_1, ..., Y_n) ] \cdot \frac{1}{ e \sqrt{m} }, \end{aligned} E[f(X1​,...,Xn​)]​=k∈N∑​E[f(X1​,...,Xn​)∣X=k]⋅Pr[X=k]≥E[f(X1​,...,Xn​)∣X=m]⋅Pr[X=m]=E[f(Y1​,...,Yn​)]⋅e−mm!mm​≥E[f(Y1​,...,Yn​)]⋅e−m(m)m(me​)mem​1​=E[f(Y1​,...,Yn​)]⋅em​1​,​

and the theorem is proven. The last inequality follows from Stirling’s formula that m!≤em(m/e)mm! \le e \sqrt{m} (m / e)^mm!≤em​(m/e)m.

□\square□

Corollary. If some event happens with probability ppp with X1,...,XnX_1, ..., X_nX1​,...,Xn​, then it happens with probability at most em⋅pe\sqrt{m} \cdot pem​⋅p with Y1,...,YnY_1, ..., Y_nY1​,...,Yn​.

Proof. Let fff be the indicator variable of the event that takes 1 if the event occurs and 0 otherwise. Then by the previous theorem,

Pr⁡[f(Y1,...,Yn)]≤emPr⁡[f(X1,...,Xn)]. \Pr[ f(Y_1, ..., Y_n) ] \le e \sqrt{m} \Pr[ f(X_1, ..., X_n) ]. Pr[f(Y1​,...,Yn​)]≤em​Pr[f(X1​,...,Xn​)].

□\square□

The analysis makes some analysis simpler since the XiX_iXi​’s are independent random variables.

In some special cases, the theorem can be strengthened.

Theorem [1]. Let f(y1,...,yn)f(y_1, ..., y_n)f(y1​,...,yn​) be a nonnegative function such that E[f(Y1,...,Yn)]\mathbb{E} [ f(Y_1, ..., Y_n) ]E[f(Y1​,...,Yn​)] is either monotonically increasing or decreasing in mmm. Then

E[f(Y1,...,Yn)]≤2E[f(X1,...,Xn)]. \mathbb{E}[ f(Y_1, ..., Y_n) ] \le 2 \mathbb{E}[ f(X_1, ..., X_n) ]. E[f(Y1​,...,Yn​)]≤2E[f(X1​,...,Xn​)].

Proof. Refer to [1]. Omitted.
